questions.question: How many sources do you need for your assignment?

choices.answer: None!
Two!
Three!
Five!

questions.question: When should you make an argument?

choices.answer: When none of the facts are known.
When everybody has the same opinion.
When you've studied both sides of the issue.
Whenever you want!
What the writer thinks or believes.
What the writer uses to prove a point.
What the writer had for lunch.
Where the writer got their information.

questions.question: How do we support our CLAIM?

choices.answer: With opinions!
With arguments!
With punctuation and spelling!
With bacon!

questions.question: Which of these is a reliable form of evidence?

choices.answer: A quote from an unknown source.
A study conducted by a known university.
A piece of paper you found with words on it.
Something you made up.

questions.question: If you have evidence from multiple sources, what's the best thing to do?

choices.answer: Mix it up! Use all of your sources.
Rely on one main source, use the others occsaionally.
Pick one source and use that.
Why use evidence?

questions.question: If I've used a bunch of quotes in my argument, what other kind of evidence should I look for?

choices.answer: Opinions/Claims
Recipes
Drawings/Sketches
Numbers/Data

questions.question: What indent style do we use on our Works Cited page?

choices.answer: First line indented.
Second line only indented.
All lines indented.
All lines after first indented.

questions.question: What job could you have where you need to know how to argue?

choices.answer: A senator!
A contractor!
A lawyer!
All of these!

questions.question: What should someone writing an argument always research?

choices.answer: How best to ignore confrontation with other views.
How the other side of an argument feels about you.
How the other side of an argument feels about your topic.
What the other side of the argument likes to eat.

questions.question: Why is it important to research and question before arguing?

choices.answer: To make sure you get your facts correct.
To make sure you make the other side feel foolish.
To be the greatest argumentative writer in history.
To conquer the galaxy! AHAHAHAHA!

questions.question: How do we recognize whether a source is based on facts or opinions?

choices.answer: All of the arguments sound true.
You've had a personal experience with one of the arguments.
Someone you know told you about it.
The arguments have sources supporting their claims.

questions.question: What's a great technique for editing your work?

choices.answer: Write two different drafts and compare them.
Write an argument from both sides of an issue and pick.
Read your work outloud to yourself to see if it sounds right
Make copies of your work and hand them out in the hall.

questions.question: Do most arguments end with one side being proven 100% correct?

choices.answer: Yes
No
YES!
NO!
